TestCase.TestCase_Title: Add a button to mono-valued variable editing

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: Plugin creation

Within Eclipse, create a new plug-in project 'testVariableEditButton'. This project shall target Eclipse version 3.8. It shall not contibute the UI and shall not be a RCP application. Let the default package name be 'testvariableeditbutton'.
Add the 'com.thalesgroup.orchestra.framework.ui' to the plugin-in dependencies.
Within the 'testvariableeditbutton' package, create a new 'TestVariableEditButton' class implementing the 'ICustomMonoValueVariableEditButton' interface.
Within the TestVariableEditButton class, implement the 'getLabel' method in order to return the "Change" string.
Within the TestVariableEditButton class, implement the 'getValue' method in order to return the "New value" string.
Make the 'testvariableeditbutton' visible from outside the plug-in.
Add a contribution to the 'com.thalesgroup.orchestra.framework.ui.customVariableEditButton' extension point
Within the contribution, add a monoValueVariable variable with path value: '\Orchestra\MyVariable'
Within the variable, add a button with class value 'testvariableeditbutton.TestVariableEditButton' and (optional) label 'Change'
Export plug-in to an Eclipse bundle in a shared directory
Test of the feature
Launch the Orchestra Framework
Create an administrator context called "AdminContext" and store it in D:\OrchestraFrameworkTests\Administrator
Unfold the "AdminContext" context in the context viewer
Click on the "Orchestra" category
Right click in the variable viewer and select "New" -> "Variable"

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: The "Variable0" variable has been added to the "Orchestra" category in the variable viewer

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: In the variable viewer, right click on the "Variable0" and select "Edit"

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: An "Edit variable" dialog box pops up

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: Fill the "Name:" textfield with value "MyVariable"
Click on the "Finish" button

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: The "Edit variable" dialog box disappears. The "Variable0" variable has been renamed to "MyVariable" in the variable viewer

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: In the variable viewer, right click on the "MyVariable" and select "Edit"

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: An "Edit variable" dialog box pops up. In the 'Unique value', ther are two buttons on the right of the text field : a 'Variables…' button and a 'Change' button.

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: In the 'Unique value' area, click on the 'Change' button

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: The textfield has been filled with 'New value' value

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: Click on the "Finish" button

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: The "Edit variable" dialog box disappears. The value of 'MyVariable' variable is now 'NewValue'

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: In the variable viewer, right click on the "MyVariable" and select "Edit"

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: An "Edit variable" dialog box pops up

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: Fill the textfield of the variable value with 'Default value'
Click on the "Finish" button

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: The "Edit variable" dialog box disappears. The value of 'MyVariable' variable is now 'Default value'

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: Create an administrator context called "InheritedAdminContext" with "AdminContext" as parent context and store it in D:\OrchestraFrameworkTests\Administrator
Unfold the "InheritedAdminContext" context in the context viewer
Click on the "Orchestra" category
In the variable viewer, right click on the 'MyVariable' variable and select "Edit" int he contextual menu

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: An "Edit variable" dialog box pops up. There are three buttons on the right of the text field : 'Restore', 'Variables…' and 'Change'

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: Click on the 'Change' button

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: The textfield has been filled with 'New value' value

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: Click on the "Finish" button

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: The "Edit variable" dialog box disappears. The value of 'MyVariable' variable is now 'New value'

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: In the variable viewer, right click on the "MyVariable" and select "Edit"

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: An "Edit variable" dialog box pops up

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: Click on the 'Restore' button

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: The textfield has been filled with 'Default value' value

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: Click on the "Finish" button

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: The "Edit variable" dialog box disappears. The value of 'MyVariable' variable is now 'Default value'

TestCase.TestCase_Title: Add a button to multi-valued variable editing

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: Plugin creation

Within Eclipse, create a new plug-in project 'testVariableEditButton'. This project shall target Eclipse version 3.8. It shall not contibute the UI and shall not be a RCP application. Let the default package name be 'testvariableeditbutton'.
Add the 'com.thalesgroup.orchestra.framework.ui' to the plugin-in dependencies.
Within the 'testvariableeditbutton' package, create a new 'TestVariableEditButton' class implementing the 'ICustomMultipleValuesVariableEditButton' interface.
Within the TestVariableEditButton class, implement the 'getLabel' method in order to return the "Change" string.
Within the TestVariableEditButton class, implement the 'getValue' method in order to return a list of three string values: "New value 1", "New value 2" and "New value 3".
Make the 'testvariableeditbutton' visible from outside the plug-in.
Add a contribution to the 'com.thalesgroup.orchestra.framework.ui.customVariableEditButton' extension point
Within the contribution, add a multipleValuesVariable variable with path value: '\Orchestra\MyVariable'
Within the variable, add a button with class value 'testvariableeditbutton.TestVariableEditButton' and (optional) label 'Change'
Export plug-in to an Eclipse bundle in a shared directory
Test of the feature
Launch the Orchestra Framework
Create an administrator context called "AdminContext" and store it in D:\OrchestraFrameworkTests\Administrator
Unfold the "AdminContext" context in the context viewer
Click on the "Orchestra" category
Right click in the variable viewer and select "New" -> "Variable"

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: The "Variable0" variable has been added to the "Category0" category in the variable viewer

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: In the variable viewer, right click on the "Variable0" and select "Edit"

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: An "Edit variable" dialog box pops up

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: Fill the "Name:" textfield with value "MyVariable"
Click on the 'Multiple values' checkbox in order to make the variable multi-valued
Click on the "Finish" button

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: The "Edit variable" dialog box disappears. The "Variable0" variable has been renamed to "MyVariable" in the variable viewer

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: In the variable viewer, right click on the "MyVariable" and select "Edit"

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: An "Edit variable" dialog box pops up. In the 'Multiple values' area, a 'Change' button has been added at the bottom of multi-valued variable edition buttons.

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: In the 'Multiple values' area, add three values : 'A', 'B', and 'C'
Click on the "Finish" button

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: The "Edit variable" dialog box disappears. In the variable viewer, the values of 'MyVariable' variable are now 'A', 'B' and 'C'

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: In the variable viewer, right click on the 'MyVariable' variable and select "Edit" int he contextual menu
Click on the "Change" button

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: Three new values have been added: 'New value 1', 'New value 2' and 'New value 3'

Step_Description.Step_Description_label: Click on the "Finish" button

Step_ExpectedResult.Step_ExpectedResult_label: The "Edit variable" dialog box disappears. In the variable viewer, the values of 'MyVariable' variable are now 'A','B', 'C', 'New value 1', 'New value 2' and 'New value 3'
